image.altText: A bald man in black tshirt and woman with long dark hair and grey jumper work in a drycleaning facility surrounded by machinery.

items.synopsis: Inflation has slowed down again, with consumer prices up 6 per cent over the year to June, below most economists' forecasts and reducing the chance of an RBA rate rise next week.

title.children: Interest rate rise now unlikely next week after inflation comes in below forecasts

image.altText: Gordi Kirkbank-Ellis side-by-side with his brain scan

items.synopsis: The effect of head knocks over Gordi Kirkbank-Ellis's decades-long sporting career isn’t immediately obvious. That is, until you see what’s happening to his brain.

title.children: From the age of 4, Gordi played contact sports. See how it has impacted his brain

image.altText: A group of volunteers surrounded by stranded pilot whales

items.synopsis: Authorities are urging the public to stay clear as they work to save the lives of the remaining 46 pilot whales stranded on Cheynes Beach.

title.children: 'Devastating': 51 whales dead on WA beach as difficult rescue effort continues

image.altText: fresh fruit in aisles of a grocery shop

items.synopsis: Consumer inflation for the June quarter falls more than expected by economists, while the IMF warns of persistent challenges for the global economy. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Inflation falls to 6 per cent as interest rate hikes dampen demand, ASX surges, IMF warns of economic challenges

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reaction to the fall in inflation is coming thick and fast. Not surprisingly, Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers has welcomed the figures. "Today’s figures from the ABS show the price pressures in our economy continue to moderate in welcome ways," he says. "It’s pleasing that inflation is moderating, and while we would prefer it moderate more quickly to ease pressure on household budgets, we are making progress. " "Inflation both here and around the world is remaining higher than we’d like for longer than we'd like, but it’s tracking downwards in the right direction." And Mr Chalmers has pointed to the government's cost of living relief measures in the budget, which include rent and energy bill assistance. "The Government’s number one priority is getting on top of the inflation challenge and providing cost-of-living relief for Australians families." "The cost-of-living relief policies are directly reducing price pressures in the economy by three quarters of a percentage point this financial year. " The budget surplus for the 2022-23 is expected to come in at around $20 billion - nearly five times the $4.2 billion predicted in May's budget. However, the Treasurer has so far ruled out additional cost of living relief measures.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasurer says making progress on inflation

children.content: Reaction to the fall in inflation is coming thick and fast.
Not surprisingly, Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers has welcomed the figures.
"Today’s figures from the ABS show the price pressures in our economy continue to moderate in welcome ways," he says.
"It’s pleasing that inflation is moderating, and while we would prefer it moderate more quickly to ease pressure on household budgets, we are making progress. "
"Inflation both here and around the world is remaining higher than we’d like for longer than we'd like, but it’s tracking downwards in the right direction."
And Mr Chalmers has pointed to the government's cost of living relief measures in the budget, which include rent and energy bill assistance.
"The Government’s number one priority is getting on top of the inflation challenge and providing cost-of-living relief for Australians families."
"The cost-of-living relief policies are directly reducing price pressures in the economy by three quarters of a percentage point this financial year. "
The budget surplus for the 2022-23 is expected to come in at around $20 billion - nearly five times the $4.2 billion predicted in May's budget.
However, the Treasurer has so far ruled out additional cost of living relief measures.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: What prices are driving services inflation? This graph from the ABS shows how the prices of selected services have behaved over the last 12 months. Starting from the left-hand side, prices have been falling for: Veterinary and other pet services (since December) Restaurant meals (since the March quarter) Maintenance & repair of dwelling (since the March quarter) But prices have been rising noticeably for: Rents (continuously for the last 12 months) Hairdressing & personal grooming services (continuously for the last 12 months) Insurance (rising continuously and exceptionally quickly since June last year) Financial services (continuously for the last 12 months) So, when you add them together, the pace of inflation in the prices of services is still increasing overall.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A further breakdown of services inflation

children.content: What prices are driving services inflation?
This graph from the ABS shows how the prices of selected services have behaved over the last 12 months.
Starting from the left-hand side, prices have been
falling
for:
Veterinary and other pet services (since December)
Restaurant meals (since the March quarter)
Maintenance
repair of dwelling (since the March quarter)
But prices have been
rising noticeably
for:
Rents (continuously for the last 12 months)
Hairdressing
personal grooming services (continuously for the last 12 months)
Insurance (rising continuously and exceptionally quickly since June last year)
Financial services (continuously for the last 12 months)
So, when you add them together, the pace of inflation in the prices of services is still increasing overall.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Investors have reacted quickly to the bigger-than-expected drop in inflation over the June quarter. The odds of a rate hike by the Reserve Bank next week have dropped, with the market betting on a 29 per cent chance of a 0.25 per cent rise, and a 71 per cent chance that rates will stay on hold. The Australian dollar slumped and the Australian market increased to a five-month high. The dollar fell nearly 1 per cent to 67.29 US cents because investors think the pull back in inflation buys the RBA more time to consider how the economy is tracking before it pulls the rate lever again. Rate hikes boost currencies because they increase the cost of money. The ASX 200 extended its gains by 0.8 per cent with investors also betting on a pause, although real estate firms are lower. Consumer staples did well on the news, but it's banks and big miners that are driving the market today. Banks extended their gains after the numbers came out. ANZ is up 1.5 per cent, while Westpac has put on 1.6 per cent. Even though banks make money from interest rate rises, higher borrowing costs also mean a likely rise in loan defaults.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Investors see RBA pause

children.content: Investors have reacted quickly to the bigger-than-expected drop in inflation over the June quarter.
The odds of a rate hike by the Reserve Bank next week have dropped, with the market betting on a 29 per cent chance of a 0.25 per cent rise, and a 71 per cent chance that rates will stay on hold.
The Australian dollar slumped and the Australian market increased to a five-month high.

The dollar fell nearly 1 per cent to 67.29 US cents because investors think the pull back in inflation buys the RBA more time to consider how the economy is tracking before it pulls the rate lever again.
Rate hikes boost currencies because they increase the cost of money.
The ASX 200
extended its gains by 0.8 per cent with investors also betting on a pause, although real estate firms are lower.
Consumer staples did well on the news, but it's banks and big miners that are driving the market today.
Banks extended their gains after the numbers came out.
ANZ is up 1.5 per cent, while Westpac has put on 1.6 per cent.
Even though banks make money from interest rate rises, higher borrowing costs also mean a likely rise in loan defaults.
